content.question: Which of the following best explains the behavior of the guard squirrels?

choices.label: The behavior of the guard squirrels increases the survival of close relatives that share the genes of the guard squirrels.
The guard squirrels confuse the predator, lowering the predatorâ€™s success rate because the predator cannot tell which squirrel is producing the sound.
Guard squirrels typically have recessive alleles, and by sacrificing themselves, they lessen the chance that recessive alleles will get passed on.
Guard squirrels are typically females who have already reproduced, so they are no longer needed by the group.

content.answer: The behavior of the guard squirrels increases the survival of close relatives that share the genes of the guard squirrels.
